Comment: This is a match I had with a player that was 1032. I'm still learning, so any comments about my moves would be great.
A lot of people say that this move is not a good counter for e4, that c5 and e6 are better. Any thoughts?
Protecting my king pawn, impeding the d4 push, and developing my knight. This game is textbook so far.
Protecting my king pawn, impeding the d4 push, and developing my knight. This game is textbook so far.
All knights developed. So far a mirrored game.
All knights developed. So far a mirrored game.
Doesn't push the pawn all the way. Good job knight on c6!
Was this a good or a bad move? I think it was good because it opened up the middle. Dunno. What do you guys think?
Threatens the queen. I've never liked this move, always thought it put the bishop in danger. Also, this move sets up the game changing pin.
Threatens the queen. I've never liked this move, always thought it put the bishop in danger. Also, this move sets up the game changing pin.
Threatens the queen. I've never liked this move, always thought it put the bishop in danger. Also, this move sets up the game changing pin.
Not the best move, I see now. But it's better than f6, and you'll see why later.
This is a blunder. See how the bishop and queen line up with c1, where the king will be if it castles queen side? This furthers the pin.
I see the opportunity, so I line up my queen and bishop for a queen pin.
The blunder I was talking about. If I can take the g5 bishop, I'll be a queen up.
I actually don't know why I did this. But it happened to really help me checkmate his king, so I guess it's a good move.
About to take the bishop. I think that my opponent thought that his queen was protecting it.
About to take the bishop. I think that my opponent thought that his queen was protecting it.
Gets ready for a discovered check, which would be good in other circumstances. However, now his queen is only being defended by his king. Thus, this is a blunder.
And the pin is here! Is it good, is it not, answer it in the comments. In this game, it changed who would win.
The discovery check I was talking about. It could have actually destroyed me, if he had played Nc6 instead of Nxg4. Then he would have taken my queen.
Was this how you would have stopped it? Also, to answer jkarp (thank you for all the comments!), I see that white could have played f4 here and my pin would be gone. Thanks for pointing that out!
This was worse than leaving the queen there, because now I can put the king in check. He should have played f4 to prevent the pin, and then he'd be up a pawn.
So there are many good moves that this guy could have done. But instead...
So there are many good moves that this guy could have done. But instead...
So there are many good moves that this guy could have done. But instead...
He makes an escape route. Bad idea, because he will never use it.
